byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

abstract: Gen John F Campbell says Special Operations Forces in Afghanistan likely did not meet their own criteria for carrying out airstrikes when authorizing strike that hit Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz; under rules, strikes are authorized to kill terrorists, protect American troops or fulfill Afghans' request for help; Campbell assumes responsibility for attack, which he suggests resulted from chain of mistakes.
lead_paragraph: Gen. John F. Campbell said the hospital was “mistakenly struck,” and said it resulted from “a U.S. decision made within the U.S. chain of command.”

headline.main: General Is Said to Think Afghan Hospital Airstrike Broke U.S. Rules
headline.print_headline: General Is Said to Think Attack Broke U.S. Rules

snippet: Gen. John F. Campbell said the hospital was “mistakenly struck,” and said it resulted from “a U.S. decision made within the U.S. chain of command.”

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
